mnd3:1.1: <em>15 : Some people truly speak with a malicious heart,
mnd3:1.2: Others say with a true heart,
mnd3:1.3: The Muni does not arrive to the arisen controversy,
mnd3:1.4: So the Muni is not desolate wherever he is.
mnd3:1.5: <em>15 : Some people truly speak with a malicious heart,
mnd3:1.6: Others say with a true heart,
mnd3:1.7: The Muni does not arrive to the arisen controversy,
mnd3:1.8: So the Muni is not desolate wherever he is.
mnd3:1.9: <em>15 : Some people truly speak with a malicious heart,
mnd3:1.10: Others say with a true heart,
mnd3:1.11: The Muni does not arrive to the arisen controversy,
mnd3:1.12: So the Muni is not desolate wherever he is.
mnd3:1.13: <em>15 : Some people truly speak with a malicious heart,
mnd3:1.14: Others say with a true heart,
mnd3:1.15: The Muni does not arrive to the arisen controversy,
mnd3:1.16: So the Muni is not desolate wherever he is.
mnd3:2.1: "Some do speak with a malicious heart": Those outsiders speak with a malicious
mnd3:2.2: heart, with a hostile heart, with a heart of opposition, a heart with of the
mnd3:2.3: blow, a heart with a backlash, a heart with harm, with the insulting heart,
mnd3:2.4: behind the back, speaking falsely, insulting the Blessed One and the Bhikkhu
mnd3:3.1: "Others do say it with a true heart": Anyone who believes in, trusts, who has a
mnd3:3.2: true mind with a true heart, who has a true mind with a factual heart, and who
mnd3:3.3: has a truthful heart, those who think truthfully, those who think with a certain
mnd3:3.4: heart, those who do not think with a heart that is inverted, (do not) say
mnd3:3.5: falsely, (dot not) insult the Blessed One and the Bhikkhu Saṅgha.
mnd3:4.1: "The controversy that has arisen, Muni does not arrive (at)": The controversy
mnd3:4.2: that has arisen, has been born, has appeared: further alley talk, insults,
mnd3:4.3: reprimands, false claims of the Blessed One and the Bhikkhu Saṅgha. "Muni does
mnd3:4.4: not reach": "Muni," Muni is called wisdom, that is wisdom, understanding...
mnd3:4.5: (omitted), no delusion, Dhamma, right view, possessing Muni wisdom, Muni. There
mnd3:4.6: are three types of Muni (perfect virtues): body Muni, language Muni, and
mnd3:5.1: What is the body of Muni? The three types of body and evil deeds are cut off as
mnd3:5.2: the Muni position; the three types of good behaviors are the Muni position; the
mnd3:5.3: wisdom in the body is the Muni position; the knowledge of the body is the Muni
mnd3:5.4: position; walking the Path with (higher) knowledge is the body of Muni; the
mnd3:5.5: abandonment of desire and greed, cut off, as the Muni; the fourth jhāna
mnd3:5.6: extinction of the body is the position of Muni.
mnd3:6.1: What is the language of Muni? The abandonment of the four types of evil deeds of
mnd3:6.2: language is the position of Muni; the four types of good acts of language are
mnd3:6.3: the position of Muni; the wisdom of linguistic objects is the position of Muni;
mnd3:6.4: the knowledge of language is the position of Muni; and knowing the path of all
mnd3:6.5: acts is the position of Muni; the abandonment of desire and greed of language is
mnd3:6.6: the position of Muni; the second jhāna cessation of language is the position of
mnd3:7.1: What is intention Muni? The three types of deeds of intention and evil deeds are
mnd3:7.2: the Muni position; the three types of good deeds are the Muni position; the
mnd3:7.3: wisdom in the mind-object is the Muni position; the knowledge of the heart is
mnd3:7.4: the Muni position; the one that walks the Path with knowledge is the position of
mnd3:7.5: Muni; the desire and greed of the heart being judged is the position of Muni;
mnd3:7.6: the desire to perish the mind is the position of Muni.
mnd3:8.1: "Body Muni, Language Muni, and Intention Muni are no troubles,
mnd3:8.2: Muni has the status of Muni, and they say he is the one who cuts everything.
mnd3:8.3: Body Muni, Language Muni, and Intention Muni are no troubles,
mnd3:8.4: Muni has the status of Muni, and they say that they are those who have been cleansed of evil."
mnd3:9.1: The six types of Muni have these three modes of Muni: Muni at home, Muni without
mnd3:9.2: a home, Muni with learning, Muni without learning, Bhikkhu Muni, Muni (of the)
mnd3:9.3: Muni. Which is at home? Those laymen who have seen the footsteps and have
mnd3:9.4: learned the precepts, these are at home. Which are homeless Muni? Those bhikkhus
mnd3:9.5: who have seen the footsteps and who have learned the precepts are homeless Muni.
mnd3:9.6: There are seven types of learning for learning Muni, Arahant for non-learning
mnd3:9.7: Muni, and Bhikkhu Buddha as Bhikkhu Muni. Muni (of) Muni is called Tathāgata,
mnd3:10.1: "Non-wise is Muni, a foolish and ignorant man,
mnd3:10.2: After raising the scale, take the top one and become a wise man.
mnd3:10.3: Avoid all evils, that Muni became Muni because of that,
mnd3:10.4: Everyone who understands the (inner and outer sum) in the world,
mnd3:10.5: Because that is said to be Muni.
mnd3:10.6: Who knows all the inside and outside of the world,
mnd3:10.7: The unwholesome and the good behind the Dhamma,
mnd3:10.8: Everyone who is supported (respected) by heaven and man,
mnd3:10.9: Beyond staining and the net, he is Muni."
mnd3:11.1: Whoever reaches the dispute, he arrives for two reasons: the person arrives at
mnd3:11.2: (the) dispute as an actor, or when he is talked of or reprimanded he was angry,
mnd3:11.3: rejected, stubborn, showing anger, aversion, dissatisfaction (, saying): "I am
mnd3:11.4: not the maker." Those who reach the dispute arrive with these two reasons. Muni
mnd3:11.5: does not reach the dispute for two reasons: Muni is not the maker, and does not
mnd3:11.6: reach (the) controversy as a maker, or when he is talked about or reprimanded,
mnd3:11.7: he does not get angry, reject, be stubborn, does not show anger, aversion,
mnd3:11.8: dissatisfaction (, saying): "I am not the maker." Muni did not arrive, does not
mnd3:11.9: arrive, does not hold, does not cling to (the) controversy, for two reasons.
mnd3:12.1: "Therefore, wherever Muni is, there is no barrenness": "Therefore," because of
mnd3:12.2: that reason, that cause, that condition, and that cause, it is a state of no
mnd3:12.3: attacking heart, a state of no desolation, no five types of barrenness of heart
mnd3:12.4: [MN.16], no three types of barrenness [SN.45.166]: the barrenness of greed, the
mnd3:12.5: barrenness of anger, the barrenness of ignorance; does not exist, is not known,
mnd3:12.6: is not discovered, has been cut off, severed, calmed down, stopped, unable to
mnd3:12.7: arise, burned by the fire of wisdom. "No matter where it is," no matter where,
mnd3:12.8: wherever, inside or outside or inside and outside.
mnd3:13.1: <em>16 : How can one cross one's own view?
mnd3:13.2: Guided by desire, fixed by (personal) inclinations (preferences),
mnd3:13.4: Indeed he will say as he knows.
mnd3:13.5: <em>16 : How can one cross one's own view?
mnd3:13.6: Guided by desire, fixed by (personal) inclinations (preferences),
mnd3:13.8: Indeed he will say as he knows.
mnd3:13.9: <em>16 : How can one cross one's own view?
mnd3:13.10: Guided by desire, fixed by (personal) inclinations (preferences),
mnd3:13.12: Indeed he will say as he knows.
mnd3:13.13: <em>16 : How can one cross one's own view?
mnd3:13.14: Guided by desire, fixed by (personal) inclinations (preferences),
mnd3:13.16: Indeed he will say as he knows.
mnd3:14.1: "How can one's own views be crossed": Anyone who kills Sundarī Nandā's female
mnd3:14.2: marchers (bhikkhunis) and declares Samaṇa Sakya's disrepute, (thinking:) "In
mnd3:14.3: this way, we will get back the benefits, reputation, respect." Those who see
mnd3:14.4: this way, people like this, lovers like this, advocates like this, and those
mnd3:14.5: with these intentions, they cannot go through their own views, their likes,
mnd3:14.6: their own inclinations, their own opinions, their own intentions; then at that
mnd3:14.7: time, the dishonour is returned to themselves. "How can this be my own view?"
mnd3:14.8: Or, "The world is everlasting, this is real, and everything else is empty."
mnd3:14.9: Whoever says this, his own views, his likes..., how can one's own intentions be
mnd3:14.10: able to cross, traverse, surpass, and overcome? What is the reason? His vision
mnd3:14.11: is completed, held, grasped, attached, and taken like that, "I have been
mnd3:14.12: convinced." How can I cross it in this way? "The world is very constant...
mnd3:14.13: (omitted) The world is bounded... The world is boundless... Fate is the body...
mnd3:14.14: Fate is one body is the other... Tathāgata exists after death... Tathāgata does
mnd3:14.15: not exist after death... The Tathāgata after death exists and does not exist...
mnd3:14.16: The Tathāgata after death neither exists nor does not exist; this is true, and
mnd3:14.17: everything else is empty." Whoever says like this, his own views, his likes,
mnd3:14.18: ..., how can they be able to cross, traverse, surpass, and overcome? What is the
mnd3:14.19: reason? His vision is completed, held, grasped, grasped, attached, taken,
mnd3:15.1: "Guided by desire, fixed by (personal) inclinations": "guided by desire," He is
mnd3:15.2: carried, taken, carried by his own views, ..., as if by carts or carriages,
mnd3:15.3: two-wheeled carts, ox carts, goat carts, ram carts, camel carts, donkeys and
mnd3:15.4: horses carts, to walk, take away, and carry. In the same way, he was driven by
mnd3:15.5: his own views, his own preferences, his own inclinations, and his own opinions,
mnd3:15.6: carried away, taken away, carried. "Fixed by (personal) inclinations," he is
mnd3:15.7: fixed, stopped, stuck, entered, stained by his own views, his own inclinations,
mnd3:15.8: and his own opinions, and turned his heart towards (a victorious solution).
mnd3:16.1: "Performing his own accomplishment": Implementing what one has done; performing
mnd3:16.2: satisfactorily; performing perfectly; performing first, most successful,
mnd3:16.3: outstanding, top, most winning: (I thought:) "This master is the all-wise man."
mnd3:16.4: Carrying out what we have done by ourselves; carrying out satisfactorily, ...,
mnd3:16.5: (Thinking:) "This Dhamma is said by the good..., this group follows
mnd3:16.6: the good... this seeing is good... this Path is based on the good... this Path
mnd3:16.7: is renunciation." The execution is done by oneself, performed satisfactorily...,
mnd3:16.8: he makes it happen, produces it makes it arise, makes it happen.
mnd3:17.1: "Indeed he will say as he knows": He will say, tell, talk, explain, and say as
mnd3:17.2: he knows, "The world is constant, this is true, and everything else is empty."
mnd3:17.3: To say, tell, talk, explain, and say, "The world is very constant...
mnd3:17.4: (omitted)..., after death, the Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist, this
mnd3:17.5: is true, and everything else is empty." He will speak, tell, talk, explain.
mnd3:18.1: <em>17 : The mortal person who tells of his own precepts and prohibitions
mnd3:18.2: To others without having been asked,
mnd3:18.3: Skillful people say that that is not the Holy Dhamma,
mnd3:18.4: Those who speak of themselves by themselves.
mnd3:18.5: <em>17 : The mortal person who tells of his own precepts and prohibitions
mnd3:18.6: To others without having been asked,
mnd3:18.7: Skillful people say that that is not the Holy Dhamma,
mnd3:18.8: Those who speak of themselves by themselves.
mnd3:18.9: <em>17 : The mortal person who tells of his own precepts and prohibitions
mnd3:18.10: To others without having been asked,
mnd3:18.11: Skillful people say that that is not the Holy Dhamma,
mnd3:18.12: Those who speak of themselves by themselves.
mnd3:18.13: <em>17 : The mortal person who tells of his own precepts and prohibitions
mnd3:18.14: To others without having been asked,
mnd3:18.15: Skillful people say that that is not the Holy Dhamma,
mnd3:18.16: Those who speak of themselves by themselves.
mnd3:19.1: "His own precepts and prohibitions": "What," what is like, such as effort, such
mnd3:19.2: as arrangement, such as type, wherever has arrived, who is khattiya, or
mnd3:19.3: Brāhmaṇa, or vessa, or sudda, or at home, or out of the home (monastics), or
mnd3:19.4: heaven, or person. "Precepts and prohibitions," there are precepts and
mnd3:19.5: prohibitions, there are prohibitions (and) non-precepts. What are precepts and
mnd3:19.6: prohibitions? Here, the bhikkhu is a preceptor, to live under the protection of
mnd3:19.7: the self-control of Pātimokkha, with sufficient righteousness and state, to see
mnd3:19.8: fear in minor sins, and to learn after accepting from a teacher. Wherever there
mnd3:19.9: is restraint, self-control, and non-violation, this is the precept; it is
mnd3:19.10: prohibition. Taking self-control as the precept; observing the righteousness as
mnd3:19.11: the prohibition is called precept and prohibition. What is the prohibition (and)
mnd3:19.12: non-precept? There are eight heads: the wild branch, the begging branch, the
mnd3:19.13: dung sweeping branch, the three clothing sticks, the second begging sticks,
mnd3:19.14: after eating, not eating sticks, often sitting (not lying) sticks, staying
mnd3:19.15: anywhere, this is called prohibition (and) non-precept. The observance of
mnd3:19.16: vitality is also called prohibition (and) precept: "I would rather leave only
mnd3:19.17: the skin, tendons, and bones; if the flesh and blood of the body is dried up, as
mnd3:19.18: long as human perseverance, human strength, human vitality, and human efforts
mnd3:19.19: should (persist) (the goal is) not achieved, there will be no stop of vitality."
mnd3:19.20: [SN.12.22] He is dedicated and diligent, like this is the observance of
mnd3:19.21: vitality, which is called prohibition (and) precept.
mnd3:20.2: Nor go out of my residence,
mnd3:20.3: Will not cause the thigh to fall (lying down),
mnd3:20.4: While the arrow of thirst is not be removed."
mnd3:21.1: He is dedicated and diligent, and the observance of such vitality is also called
mnd3:21.2: prohibition (and) precept. "As long as my mind is not free from all defilements
mnd3:21.3: by not clinging, I will not break this cross-legged (posture)!" [MN.32] He is
mnd3:21.4: dedicated, hardworking, and observing such vitality is also called prohibition
mnd3:21.5: (and) precept. "As long as my mind is not free from all the troubles by not
mnd3:21.6: clinging, I will not rise from this seat..., I will not walk down from the
mnd3:21.7: experience.., I will not go out from the dwelling..., I will not go out from the
mnd3:21.8: half-roofed house..., ...from the tall building..., the flat-roofed house, the
mnd3:21.9: cave (cavern), the cave (grotto), the hut, the heavy pavilion, the observation
mnd3:21.10: deck, the round house, the shed, the lecture hall, the tend, ...I will not go
mnd3:22.1: "Just before this noon I will acquire, fully obtain, attain, reach, and testify
mnd3:22.2: about the Holy Dhamma"..., "Just this noon..., in the evening..., before eating,
mnd3:22.3: after eating, before the night, midnight, after the night, at the time of death,
mnd3:22.4: at the time of the white moon, in the rainy season, in the winter, in the
mnd3:22.5: summer, in youth, in middle age, in old age, I will acquire, fully obtain,
mnd3:22.6: attain, reach, and testify about the Holy Dhamma." He is dedicated and diligent,
mnd3:22.7: and the observance of such vitality is also called prohibition (and) precept.
mnd3:22.8: "Humans" are sentient beings, human beings, student Brāhmaṇas, people,
mnd3:22.9: individuals, lives, those born to people, those born to Indā, and Manu.
mnd3:23.1: "Speaking about (the above) without having been asked by other people": "To
mnd3:23.2: other people," to other khattiya, Brāhmaṇa, .... "Not to be asked," not being
mnd3:23.3: questioned, not being asked, not being begged, not being inquired of, not being
mnd3:23.4: asked to make clear. "Say," speak of one's precepts, or prohibitions, or
mnd3:23.5: precepts and prohibitions: I am a "person of sufficient precepts," or
mnd3:23.6: "sufficient in prohibitions," "in precepts and prohibitions, one who is
mnd3:23.7: sufficient," either by birth, or by surname, or by good family, or by appearance
mnd3:23.8: and beauty as a lotus, or by property, or by research (acquisition), or by
mnd3:23.9: profession, either by skill, or by study, or by what you have heard, or by
mnd3:23.10: arguing, or "being a bhikkhu from your family," or "being a bhikkhu from a big
mnd3:23.11: family," or "from a big family" a wealthy bhikkhu, or a bhikkhu from a wealthy
mnd3:23.12: wealthy family, or a bhikkhu who is in the same household and a bhikkhu is a
mnd3:23.13: well-known person or a famous person, or on clothing, food, shelter, necessities
mnd3:23.14: of the patient, and medical necessities, or "teacher," or "lawyer," or
mnd3:23.15: "speaker," or "lives in the forest," or "begging," or "wearing dung and sweeping
mnd3:23.16: clothes," or "but the three-clothed person," or "the second beggar," or "the
mnd3:23.17: person who does not eat after eating (eating once)," or "the person who often
mnd3:23.18: sits (not lying)," or "the person who lives anywhere," or "the first jhāna
mnd3:23.19: person," or "the obtainer of the second jhāna," or "the obtainer of the third
mnd3:23.20: jhāna," or "the obtainer of the fourth jhāna," or "the obtainer who waits in the
mnd3:23.21: boundless void (fifth/first immaterial)," or "the one who waits in the boundless
mnd3:23.22: consciousness (sixth)," or "the gainer who waits in nothingness (seventh)," "the
mnd3:23.23: gainer who does not wait in nothingness (neither perception nor
mnd3:23.24: non-perception)," he speaks, tells, talks, explains, and says.
mnd3:24.1: "Skillful ones say that that is not the Holy Dhamma": "Skillful ones," those
mnd3:24.2: who possess skill, those skilled in the realm, those who are dependent on the
mnd3:24.3: skillful, those who mindful of the skillful, those who are diligent and
mnd3:24.4: skillful, the sacred and skillful, the root and the skillful, the good, those
mnd3:24.5: who are righteous, the skilful in the Path, the skillful in the Fruit, the
mnd3:24.6: skillful people of Nibbāna, those skillful ones say this: "This is the unsagely
mnd3:24.7: Dhamma, this is not the Dhamma of the sage, this is the Dhamma of the fool, this
mnd3:24.8: is not the Dhamma of the wise, this is the Dhamma of the non-good people, this
mnd3:24.9: is not the Dhamma of the good people." They tell, speak, explain, and say so.
mnd3:25.1: "Anyone who speaks of himself": He is called himself. "Speak by yourself," speak
mnd3:25.2: of yourself as "I am a 'sufficient person,' or a 'restricted person,' or
mnd3:25.3: 'precept and prohibitions are enough' ...(omitted)...," he says, talks,
mnd3:26.1: <em>18 : A silent bhikkhu, a person in a completely cooled state,
mnd3:26.2: Does not boast "I am like this" in the precepts,
mnd3:26.3: The skillful people say that it is the Holy Dhamma,
mnd3:26.4: For him there is no increase anywhere in the world.
mnd3:26.5: <em>18 : A silent bhikkhu, a person in a completely cooled state,
mnd3:26.6: Does not boast "I am like this" in the precepts,
mnd3:26.7: The skillful people say that it is the Holy Dhamma,
mnd3:26.8: For him there is no increase anywhere in the world.
mnd3:26.9: <em>18 : A silent bhikkhu, a person in a completely cooled state,
mnd3:26.10: Does not boast "I am like this" in the precepts,
mnd3:26.11: The skillful people say that it is the Holy Dhamma,
mnd3:26.12: For him there is no increase anywhere in the world.
mnd3:26.13: <em>18 : A silent bhikkhu, a person in a completely cooled state,
mnd3:26.14: Does not boast "I am like this" in the precepts,
mnd3:26.15: The skillful people say that it is the Holy Dhamma,
mnd3:26.16: For him there is no increase anywhere in the world.
mnd3:27.1: "Silent bhikkhus, those who are in a completely cooled state": "silent," the
mnd3:27.2: greed has subsided so the state is silent; the anger has subsided so the state
mnd3:27.4: stinginess, fraud, cunning, stubbornness, passion, sloth, extreme sloth, torpor,
mnd3:27.5: indulgence; covered by all pollution, all evil deeds, all troubles, all
mnd3:27.6: scorching heat, all irritations, covered by all bad practices, expanded
mnd3:27.7: coverage, upper coverage, obstruction (blocking), enveloping, obstructing,
mnd3:27.8: closing, covering; all unwholesome contrived state has been silenced, calmed
mnd3:27.9: down, cooled down, the extinguished state, the cooled state, the departed state,
mnd3:27.10: and the cessation state are silent, still, calmed, cooled, stopped.
mnd3:28.1: "Bhikkhu," the state of the destroyed seven dhammas is a Bhikkhu: seeing is
mnd3:28.2: destroyed, suspicion is destroyed, prohibition is destroyed, greed is destroyed,
mnd3:28.3: anger is destroyed, delusion is destroyed, sloth is destroyed, and those evil
mnd3:28.4: and unwholesome dhammas are destroyed; shunning the pollution, the others, the
mnd3:28.5: fear, the bitter fruit, old age and death in the future.
mnd3:29.2: "Take the path I have practiced to reach Nibbāna and transcend skeptics,
mnd3:29.4: The one who has been completed, and the one who is extinct, is a Bhikkhu."
mnd3:30.1: "Silent Bhikkhus, those in a state of being completely cooled": Those who make
mnd3:30.2: the state of greed extinguished are those in the state of being completely
mnd3:31.1: "I don't boast about 'I am like this' in the precepts: "I am like this," the
mnd3:31.2: continuation of the sentences; the connection of the sentences; the consummation
mnd3:31.3: of the sentences; the combination of words; the connection of words; this is a
mnd3:31.4: second sentence; this is "I am like this." "I don't boast in the precepts."
mnd3:31.5: Here, there is a type of boasting: I am a "restricted person," ...(omitted)....
mnd3:31.6: In this way he does not boast or show off. He has been separated from boasting,
mnd3:31.7: has renounced, has abandoned, has given up, has been separated, has been freed,
mnd3:31.8: has renounced bondage, he lives with an unrestrained heart.
mnd3:32.1: "Skillful ones say that it is the Holy Dhamma": "Skillful ones," ..., those
mnd3:32.2: skillful people say: "This is the righteous Dhamma, this is not the Dhamma of
mnd3:32.3: the unrighteous, this is the Dhamma of the wise, this is not the Dhamma of the
mnd3:32.4: fool, this is the Dhamma of the virtuous man, this is not the Dhamma of the
mnd3:32.5: unvirtuous man." They say so, speak so, tell so, explain so, say so.
mnd3:33.1: "For him increase (surge, growth) does not exist anywhere in the world": "For
mnd3:33.2: him," for the Arahant, for those who have exhausted troubles. "Surge," there are
mnd3:33.3: seven surges: greed, aggression, delusion, sloth, seeing, pollution, kamma
mnd3:33.4: increases. For those people, these increases are not, do not exist, are not
mnd3:33.5: known, and have not been discovered; cut off, severed, calmed down, stopped,
mnd3:33.6: unable to arise, burned by the fire of wisdom. "No matter where," no matter
mnd3:33.7: where, wherever, inside or outside or (both) inside and outside. "In the world,"
mnd3:33.8: in the world of suffering, the world of humans, the world of heaven, the world
mnd3:33.9: of aggregates, the world of realms, the world of places.
mnd3:34.1: <em>19 : All the dhammas that are fixed for him,
mnd3:34.4: Is a dependent who shakes the silence.
mnd3:34.5: <em>19 : All the dhammas that are fixed for him,
mnd3:34.8: Is a dependent who shakes the silence.
mnd3:34.9: <em>19 : All the dhammas that are fixed for him,
mnd3:34.12: Is a dependent who shakes the silence.
mnd3:34.13: <em>19 : All the dhammas that are fixed for him,
mnd3:34.16: Is a dependent who shakes the silence.
mnd3:35.1: "All the dhammas that are fixed for him, which are valued": "Fixed (constant)
mnd3:35.2: view," there are two types of fixed views: .... "Proactive," Proactive,
mnd3:35.3: pretentious, and cohabiting, are active. In addition, the impermanence, the
mnd3:35.4: action, the condition-born are the dhammas of the extinction, the dissipation,
mnd3:35.5: the fading, and the dhammas, are also active. "Whatever is for him" is for those
mnd3:35.6: who see evil. "Dhamma" It is called the sixty-two evil views.
mnd3:36.1: "Being valued (and) impure": "Being valued," there are two types of importance:
mnd3:36.2: of thirst and of views. What is the thirst? All are called boundaries, realms,
mnd3:36.3: scopes, borders, are grasped, and are treated as one's own: this is mine, this
mnd3:36.4: is mine, so much is mine, this area is mine; (my) form, sound, smell, taste,
mnd3:36.5: touch, things on the ground, coats, maids and male servants, goats and sheep,
mnd3:36.6: chickens and pigs, elephants, cows and horses, mules, fields, homesteads, gold,
mnd3:36.7: coins, villages, towns, capitals, places, treasuries, warehouses, all the land;
mnd3:36.8: because they are craving and regard them as their own, all one-hundred-and-eight
mnd3:37.1: What is the views? There are twenty views of the body, ten evil views, ten side
mnd3:37.2: views, all views like this, evil views, jungle (entangled) views, desert
mnd3:37.3: (barren) views, distorted views, shaken views; the clinging, acceptance,
mnd3:37.4: holding, grasping to the bound view, the place where the evil way, the evil
mnd3:37.5: nature, the outside way depend, the clasping of the inversion (vipariyesa), the
mnd3:37.6: clinging of the inversion (viparīta), the inversion (vipallāsa), the grip of the
mnd3:37.7: evil, the clasping of evil, the grip of "(seeing) the real in the unreal," all
mnd3:37.8: come to the reach of the sixty-two evil views.
mnd3:38.1: For him, the importance of thirst is not cut off, the importance of seeing has
mnd3:38.2: not been cut off, the state of the importance of thirst is not cut off, the
mnd3:38.3: state of the importance of seeing is not cut off, he puts thirst for love or
mnd3:38.4: seeing ahead before and walks, thirst as a flag, thirst as a pillar, thirst
mnd3:38.5: increases, seen as flag, seen as tower, seen as increase, following desire to
mnd3:38.6: love or see. "Existence," to be, to be known, to have, to be discovered.
mnd3:39.1: "Whoever sees benefits in oneself": "Oneself" is on the self. He is called (one
mnd3:39.2: who has the) evil view, and he sees two benefits of his own view: the benefit in
mnd3:39.3: life and the benefit in the afterlife. What is the life benefit of seeing (this
mnd3:39.4: view)? Every view that the master has, so do the disciples. For that view of the
mnd3:39.5: master, the disciples respect, admire, adore, and respect, because of that he
mnd3:39.6: gets clothes, food, shelter, patients' necessities, and medical necessities,
mnd3:39.7: this is the immediate benefit of seeing. What is the afterlife benefit of seeing
mnd3:39.8: (this view)? "This seeing is enough to become the state of the dragon (dragon
mnd3:39.9: world), or the state of the golden-winged bird, or the state of the Yakkha, or
mnd3:39.10: the state of Asura, or the state of Gandhabba, or the state of the king, or the
mnd3:39.11: state of Indā, or the state of Brahma, or the state of heaven, this view is
mnd3:39.12: pure, clean, all pure; detachment, liberation, breaking away, from all over, to
mnd3:39.13: see them become pure, to become purified, to become pure; to be detached, to be
mnd3:39.14: liberated, to be freed, to see that I will become pure, to become purified, to
mnd3:39.15: become pure; to escape, be liberated, and be detached everywhere." For the
mnd3:39.16: expectation of future fruit, this is the afterlife benefit of seeing. He sees,
mnd3:39.17: watches, stares, contemplates, and observes the two benefits of his own view.
mnd3:40.1: "He is a dependent who shakes the stillness (silence)": There are three types of
mnd3:40.2: stillness: ultimate stillness, temporal stillness, and worldly stillness. What
mnd3:40.3: is ultimate silence? Ultimate silence is called non-living, Nibbāna, where all
mnd3:40.4: those actions cease, all dependent cessation, the cessation of craving, greed,
mnd3:40.5: extinction, and Nibbāna, this is ultimate silence. What is temporal silence? For
mnd3:40.6: those who enter the first jhāna, the gazes are silenced; for those who enter the
mnd3:40.7: second jhāna, searching is silenced; for those who enter the third jhāna, their
mnd3:40.8: their joy is silenced; for those who enter the fourth jhāna, their happiness
mnd3:40.9: (and suffering) are quiet; for those who enter the boundless void (fifth/first
mnd3:40.10: immaterial), lust, thinking, and all types of desires are silenced; for those
mnd3:40.11: who enter the boundlessness of consciousness (sixth), the boundless void is
mnd3:40.12: quiet; for those who enter nothingness (seventh) it is said that knowledge has
mnd3:40.13: no bounds is silenced; for those who enter the non-imaginary place (eighth,
mnd3:40.14: neither perception nor non-perception) and wait, nothingness is silenced, this
mnd3:40.15: is the part of silence. What is worldly silence? The sixty-two evil views, the
mnd3:40.16: stillness of seeing is called secular stillness, and in this sense it is secular
mnd3:40.17: stillness: it has the meaning of "silence." "He is a dependent shaking the
mnd3:40.18: stillness": He is shaking stillness, strong shaking stillness, moving stillness,
mnd3:40.19: fluctuating stillness, impacting stillness, constructed stillness, fixed view,
mnd3:40.20: silence is impermanent, active, and conditioned; it is the dependent, stuck,
mnd3:41.1: <em>20 : The attachment to seeing (views) is indeed not easy to overcome:
mnd3:41.2: It is held tightly after being selected among Dhammas,
mnd3:41.5: <em>20 : The attachment to seeing (views) is indeed not easy to overcome:
mnd3:41.6: It is held tightly after being selected among Dhammas,
mnd3:41.9: <em>20 : The attachment to seeing (views) is indeed not easy to overcome:
mnd3:41.10: It is held tightly after being selected among Dhammas,
mnd3:41.13: <em>20 : The attachment to seeing (views) is indeed not easy to overcome:
mnd3:41.14: It is held tightly after being selected among Dhammas,
mnd3:42.1: "The attachment to seeing (views) is indeed not easy to overcome": The
mnd3:42.2: attachment to seeing, "The world is constant, this is real, and everything else
mnd3:42.3: is empty." The persistence, clinging to the dwelling place of seeing (the view);
mnd3:42.4: "The world is very constant...," ...(omitted)... "The obsession of seeing is
mnd3:42.5: indeed not easy to overcome": The obsession of seeing is indeed not easy to
mnd3:42.6: overcome, difficult to surpass, difficult to escape, difficult to transcend,
mnd3:42.7: difficult to pass, and difficult to overcome.
mnd3:43.1: "After selecting among the Dhammas, it is held tightly": "In the Dhamma," in the
mnd3:43.2: sixty-two evil views. "After selection," after decision, after judgment, after
mnd3:43.3: measurement, after evaluation, after judgment, after separation, after
mnd3:43.4: clarification. "To be grasped," limited grasp, partial grasp, uppermost grasp,
mnd3:43.5: fixed amount grasp, accumulation grasp: this is true, truthful, facts,
mnd3:43.6: correctness, and not inverted, to be held, clenched, clinging, taken, believed
mnd3:44.2: "In those attachments," in those attachments of seeing (views).
mnd3:45.1: "Rejection and holding of the Dhamma": "Rejection," he refuses for two reasons:
mnd3:45.2: he refuses by interruption by others, or he refuses when it is not reached (by
mnd3:45.3: him). How to refuse by interruption by others? Judgment: That master is not the
mnd3:45.4: all wise man, the Dhamma is not said to be good, (its) groups (of people) are
mnd3:45.5: not those who do what is good, seeing is not good, the path is not set up by the
mnd3:45.6: good, the path is not detached, there is no purity here, or purification, or all
mnd3:45.7: over pure; or free, or liberated, or all out, it's inferior, despicable, low,
mnd3:45.8: trivial, inferior intent, insignificant; and this is "interrupted by others." In
mnd3:45.9: this way, when interrupted, he rejects the master, the narration of the Dhamma,
mnd3:45.10: the group, and the meeting, refuse the path, reject the Path, so that it is
mnd3:45.11: "interrupted by others." How does he refuse when it is not reached (by him)? He
mnd3:45.12: rejects when the precept is not reached, he rejects when the prohibition is not
mnd3:45.13: reached, and when the precept and prohibition are not reached, he refuses, so he
mnd3:45.14: refuses when it is not reached. "And grasping," he grasps the master, grasps the
mnd3:45.15: narration, grasps the group, grasps the view, grasps the way, grasps the path,
mnd3:46.2: There is no place in the world where there are all types of views,
mnd3:46.3: After the cleansed one has abandoned deception and conceit,
mnd3:46.6: There is no place in the world where there are all types of views,
mnd3:46.7: After the cleansed one has abandoned deception and conceit,
mnd3:46.10: There is no place in the world where there are all types of views,
mnd3:46.11: After the cleansed one has abandoned deception and conceit,
mnd3:46.14: There is no place in the world where there are all types of views,
mnd3:46.15: After the cleansed one has abandoned deception and conceit,
mnd3:47.1: "For those who are cleansed, there is indeed no place in the world, where there
mnd3:47.2: are all types of (incorrect) views (of existence)": "Cleansing," cleansing is
mnd3:47.3: called wisdom, which is wisdom...(omitted) For what reason is cleansed called
mnd3:47.4: Wisdom? With that wisdom, the evil deeds of the body are shaken off, cleansed,
mnd3:47.5: completely cleansed, and washed away; the evil deeds of speech...; malevolent
mnd3:47.6: acts..., greed...; anger, ignorance, ...(omitted)...; all pollution, all evil
mnd3:47.7: deeds, all troubles, all scorching heat, all heat troubles, all unwholesome
mnd3:47.8: deeds are shaken off, washed, completely washed, and separated by washing, for
mnd3:47.9: this reason cleansing is called wisdom.
mnd3:48.1: Or, evil views are shaken off..., washed away by right views; evil words...,
mnd3:48.2: right words; evil kamma..., right deeds; evil destiny..., righteous destiny;
mnd3:48.3: evil spirit..., righteous effort; evil thoughts..., right thoughts; evil
mnd3:48.4: deeds..., right concentration; evil wisdom..., right wisdom; evil liberation...,
mnd3:48.5: right liberation; cleansed, completely cleansed, and washed away.
mnd3:49.1: Or, all pollution, all evil deeds, all afflictions, all scorching heat, all heat
mnd3:49.2: afflictions, all unwholesome deeds are shaken off, cleansed, completely
mnd3:49.3: cleansed, and separated by cleansing by the eight holy paths, and the Arahant
mnd3:49.4: possesses, fully possesses, enters, fully enters, fully-sufficient,
mnd3:49.5: fully-satisfied, possessing these dhammas that can be cleansed. Therefore, the
mnd3:49.6: Arahant is a cleansed person. He is the one who shakes off the greed, the evil,
mnd3:49.7: the pollution, and the heat (irritation). "No matter where," no matter where,
mnd3:49.8: anywhere, wherever, inside or outside or (both) inside and outside. "In the
mnd3:49.9: world," in the world of the suffering world... (omitted).
mnd3:50.1: There are two types of fixed views: the fixed views because of desire and the
mnd3:50.2: fixed views of seeing (views)... (omitted). "In all types of existence," in all
mnd3:50.3: types of kamma, the desire to have again; in the desire to have, the form of
mnd3:50.4: existence; in the form of existence, the formlessness again; in the kamma of the
mnd3:50.5: formless existence, repeating again and again; in the repeated interest, in the
mnd3:50.6: rebirth; in the rebirth, the individual birth. For those who are cleansed, no
mnd3:50.7: matter where they are in the world, there are indeed no views, and there are
mnd3:50.8: (none of) all types of fixed views: for those who are cleansed, no matter where
mnd3:50.9: in the world, construction of all types of things, fixed, contrived, making
mnd3:50.10: cohabitation with views, he is not, does not exist, is not known, is not
mnd3:50.11: discovered, has been cut off, severed, calmed down, stopped, unable to arise,
mnd3:50.12: burned by the fire of wisdom.
mnd3:51.1: "The person who cleans up abandons deception and conceit": Deception is called
mnd3:51.2: deception. Here, after a certain type of person performs evil deeds with the
mnd3:51.3: body; after the evil deeds with the language; after the evil deeds with the
mnd3:51.4: intention, the desire to hide the evil is established. He wants: "May he not
mnd3:51.5: know me (my deeds, etc.)!" He doesn't want to know me!" Says "May he not know
mnd3:51.6: me!" working hard physically, "May he not know me!" [AN.6.45] In cases of
mnd3:51.7: deception, cross-border (violation), concealment, obfuscation, keeping secrets,
mnd3:51.8: hiding, concealing (keeping secrets all over), covering, covering all over,
mnd3:51.9: undisclosed acts, and covering up evil acts are called deceptions.
mnd3:52.1: "Conceit," one type of conceit: that is the height of the heart; two types...:
mnd3:52.2: self praise is conceited, contempt for others is conceited; three: "I am the
mnd3:52.3: winner"..., "I am the same," "I am the inferior;" four: to gain, to have fame,
mnd3:52.4: praise, and comfort; five: "I obtain the desired form," "I obtain the desired
mnd3:52.5: sound," smell..., taste..., touch....; six types: with eyes..., ears..., nose,
mnd3:52.6: tongue, body, ...satisfaction of the mind makes one conceited; seven: conceit,
mnd3:52.7: arrogance, conceit and arrogance, humbleness, conceit of increase, conceit of
mnd3:52.8: self-reality, conceit of evil; eight: obtaining makes one conceited, not
mnd3:52.9: obtaining..., fame, no fame, praise, rebuke, happiness, and suffering; nine: the
mnd3:52.10: winner thinks: "I am the winner"..., the winner thinks: "I am the same," the
mnd3:52.11: winner thinks: "I am the inferior"...; and equal think: "I am the winner," the
mnd3:52.12: equal thinks: "I am the same," the equal thinks: "I am the inferior," the
mnd3:52.13: inferior thinks: "I am the winner," the inferior thinks: "I am the same," the
mnd3:52.14: inferior thinks: "I am the inferior;" ten types...: here, by certain birth, or
mnd3:52.15: surname, or good family, or beauty like a lotus, or property, or research
mnd3:52.16: (acquisition), or career, or craftsmanship, or study, or by what you hear, or by
mnd3:52.17: arguing, or by something to make one conceited; anyone who, like this, with this
mnd3:52.18: type of heart conceit, thinking, perceiving the situation, high tribute, high
mnd3:52.19: conceit, as a banner, as a flag, heart vanity is called conceited. "The cleansed
mnd3:52.20: one abandons the deceit and conceit": After the cleansed one abandons, after
mnd3:52.21: discarding, after being driven away, after finishing, and making it go to
mnd3:53.1: "He is a non-attached person, what would he fall into?": "Attachment," there are
mnd3:53.2: two types of attachments.... For him, the attachment to love has been cut off;
mnd3:53.3: the attachment to seeing (views) has been cut off, the state of attachment to
mnd3:53.4: seeing has been cut off; not-attached people will fall in with what greed, with
mnd3:53.5: what aversion, with what delusion, with what conceit, with what perception, with
mnd3:53.6: what doubt, what type of potential trouble, and become the "infected," or
mnd3:53.7: "disgusting," or "ignorant," or "bound," or "attacker," or "coming to the
mnd3:53.8: scattered chaos," or "coming to the unsatisfactory," or "coming to the
mnd3:53.9: stalwart?" What type of state will the state where the deeds have been cut off
mnd3:53.10: and the deeds will fall into the interesting place and become "in hell," or "the
mnd3:53.11: animal world," or "hungry ghost world," or "human," or "heaven," or "formed," or
mnd3:53.12: "formless," or "thinking," or "not thinking," or "neither a thinker nor a
mnd3:53.13: thoughtless one?" He has no cause, no predestiny, and no factors that will fall
mnd3:54.1: <em>22 : The involved one has indeed reached a dispute on the various dhammas,
mnd3:54.2: (But) what could one dispute about with one who who has no attachment?
mnd3:54.3: What is taken and rejected do not exist for him,
mnd3:54.4: And he wiped out everything (views) in this life.
mnd3:54.5: <em>22 : The involved one has indeed reached a dispute on the various dhammas,
mnd3:54.6: (But) what could one dispute about with one who who has no attachment?
mnd3:54.7: What is taken and rejected do not exist for him,
mnd3:54.8: And he wiped out everything (views) in this life.
mnd3:54.9: <em>22 : The involved one has indeed reached a dispute on the various dhammas,
mnd3:54.10: (But) what could one dispute about with one who who has no attachment?
mnd3:54.11: What is taken and rejected do not exist for him,
mnd3:54.12: And he wiped out everything (views) in this life.
mnd3:54.13: <em>22 : The involved one has indeed reached a dispute on the various dhammas,
mnd3:54.14: (But) what could one dispute about with one who who has no attachment?
mnd3:54.15: What is taken and rejected do not exist for him,
mnd3:54.16: And he wiped out everything (views) in this life.
mnd3:55.1: "Involved people have indeed reached controversy in all dhammas": "Involvement,"
mnd3:55.2: there are two types of involvement: the craving and seeing.... For him, the
mnd3:55.3: involvement of thirst has not been cut off; the involvement of seeing has not
mnd3:55.4: been cut off, in the state of being unbroken, the state of involvement of seeing
mnd3:55.5: reached disputes in the dhamma, becoming the "infected," or the "disgusting," or
mnd3:55.6: the "stupid," or the "bound," or the "holding," or "coming to disorganization,"
mnd3:55.7: or "coming to the undesirable," or "coming to the fortitude," the state of the
mnd3:55.8: unremoved, the unresolved state of the creations, in the interest of the
mnd3:55.9: controversy, becomes the "fall to hell people," or "those who fell into the
mnd3:55.10: animal world," or "those who fell into the hungry ghost world," or "human," or
mnd3:55.11: "heaven," or "formed," or "formless," or "thinking," or " the non-thinking
mnd3:55.12: person, or the "neither the thinking nor non-thinking person," he arrives,
mnd3:56.1: "How and by what can be said of the non-attached one": "Attachment," there are
mnd3:56.2: two types of attachment: .... For him, the attachment of thirst has been cut
mnd3:56.3: off...; with what greed..., in terms of the underlying tendency of trouble, can
mnd3:56.4: you say that the non-attachment person is the "infected," or the "disgusting,"
mnd3:56.5: or the "ignorant," or the "bound," or the "attacker," or "coming to
mnd3:56.6: disorganization," or "coming to the unsatisfactory," or "coming to the
mnd3:56.7: stalwart?" What can be said of the state in which the deeds have been cut
mnd3:56.8: off.... He has no cause, no fate, there are no factors that can be spoken of,
mnd3:56.9: can be talked of, can be explained, and can be said.
mnd3:57.1: "Taking and rejecting do not exist for him": The "taking" is for "me," he does
mnd3:57.2: not have this; the "rejection" is for the extinction, he does not have this; the
mnd3:57.3: "taking" is the grasping, ...and the "rejection" is the one that should be
mnd3:57.4: released.... Anything that should be held, there is something that should be
mnd3:57.5: released; everything that should be released, there are those that should be
mnd3:57.6: held. Taking and rejecting has been surpassed, and the Arahant has surpassed
mnd3:57.7: consciousness and retreat. He is a person who has descended into a state, who
mnd3:57.8: has practiced, who has completed the journey, who has reached the direction, the
mnd3:57.9: cycle of life and death, without his rebirth.
mnd3:58.1: "In this life he sweeps away all views": For him, the sixty-two evil views have
mnd3:58.2: been cut off, severed, calmed down, stopped, unable to arise, burned by the fire
mnd3:58.3: of wisdom, and all evil views, he swept, shook off, shakes off completely,
mnd3:58.4: shakes down, gives up, drives away,s make to end, makes them to go to
